item.title: The Nature of Computing
item.description:
In his book The Nature of Technology, W. Brian Arthur describes technology as combinations of other technologies. This description poses a couple of questions for software.

First, take a program like Git. To figure out what technologies Git is made of, perhaps all we have to do is inspect its dependencies? Surprisingly, Git has few real dependencies.¹

Second, note how Arthur’s description of technology is recursive — where does it end? His answer is in elemental technologies. These are technologies which deliver an effect based on a natural phenomenon:
